project.name: Configuration Java demo
project.description: Kaa Configuration subsystem demo app based on Java SDK
project.details:
This simple app demonstrates capabilities of the Kaa Configuration subsystem on the Java SDK.

Installation

Download the jar file to your device by clicking the "Binary" button on the left. Make sure that you have Java installed on your device. Run the application using the following command in the console: 
$ java -jar ConfigurationDemo.jar

Playing around

Make sure that the Kaa Sandbox is up and running. After starting the "Configuration Java demo" app, you will obtain the latest configuration accessible by the endpoint. This configuration is provided as a list of links to Kaa documentation.

Now it's time to test things out: navigate to the Kaa server administrative interface by clicking the "Administrative console" link at the top of the Sandbox window. Log in as a tenant developer (devuser / devuser123), and navigate to the "Configuration demo" application, then select "Endpoint groups". From here you can manage endpoint groups and update endpoint configuration. Make sure you have tried updating configuration for endpoint group "All" and received it on your device. Do not forget to activate the updated configuration â€” otherwise the endpoint will not be able to receive it.

Please note that all the features of Administration UI are also supported by REST API.

What's next?

For more background on the Kaa Configuration subsystem please refer to the corresponding programming guide and design reference sections..

project.name: Configuration C++ demo
project.description: Kaa Configuration subsystem demo app based on C++ SDK
project.details:
This sample application uses the Configuration Extension based on the Kaa C++ SDK. This extension enables Kaa client to update the endpoint configuration by receiving the data from Kaa server. The default configuration is statically stored in the Kaa SDK and is used in case no updates from the Operations service are available. The latest configuration is stored locally in the configuration storage and can be obtained regardless of the Operations service availability. This sample application stores the configuration in the saved_config.cfg file located in the sample application working directory.

Launching

To launch this sample application on the Kaa C++ SDK:
  1. Prepare your C++ SDK environment. To do this, follow the instructions in Using Kaa endpoint SDKs.
  2. Click the Source button. A project source download window will open. Click Ok and download the .tar.gz file.
  3. Unpack the downloaded archive and run the following command from the directory containing the unpacked source files.

    Windows 

    					build.bat deploy

    Linux, OS X (macOS) 

    					./build.sh deploy

  4. The program will ask you to enter the target platform for your build. Press Enter to specify the x86-64 platform (default) or enter the name of one of the supported platforms and press Enter. The C++ SDK and the demo application are now built and the demo application is launched.
Once you built the application, you can start it at any time using the following command.

Windows 

			build.bat run

Linux, OS X (macOS) 

			./build.sh run

Troubleshooting

Running the build.sh script returns an error message

		Please, put the generated C/C++ SDK tarball into the libs/kaa folder and re-run the script.

This means that no SDK tarball was found in the libs/kaa directory.

Try the following:
  • Download and install the Kaa Sandbox. To do this, follow the instructions in Getting started.
  • Download the SDK tarball for this sample application and put it in the libs/kaa folder. To do this, follow the instructions in Generating SDK.

CMake returns an error message

		CMake Error: The following variables are used in this project, but they are set to NOTFOUND: (...)

This means that CMake could not find the required libraries because they were not installed correctly. To address this issue, check if you completed all the required steps of the C++ SDK installation instructions.

Error during compilation

		c++: Internal compiler error: Killed (program cc1plus)

This error can occur due to insufficient memory available to the compiler. By default, the sample applications and SDK based on C++ are compiled using the four-threaded parallelism mode. This may cause failures on low-performance systems.

Try restarting your build in the single-threaded mode. Run the make command from the build directory of the sample application.

For more information, see:
  • General troubleshooting page.
  • C++ SDK installation guide for Linux (host).
